Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate how physiological changes regulate protein-based inheritance in yeast. Protein-based heritable elements (prions), particularly in fungi, are novel genetic elements that produce heritable changes in their host cells without any change in the DNA of their genes. This effect is achieved by switching between protein conformations (termed isoforms) one of which (the prion isoform) is able to reproduce itself by inducing other molecules of the same protein to switch into the same (prion) isoform. This project looks specifically at how these transitions are aided by another class of proteins, termed molecular chaperones, whose normal function is to promote correct protein folding and prevent protein misfolding. Understanding the physiological control of protein-based inheritance has a potential impact on the industrial use of yeast and other fungi. The research is integrated with course development, teaching and mentoring, thus assuring educational benefits in the areas of genetics, biochemistry and bionanotechnology. The research team includes both men and women graduate and undergraduate students, and a diverse team will be deliberately maintained. This project will also help to strengthen research infrastructure by contributing to the development of interdisciplinary centers at Georgia Institute of Technology.

The main objective of this project is to uncover the pathway connecting the protein synthesizing ribosomal machinery to the cellular apparatus of heritable protein aggregation. The unifying hypothesis is that the ribosome-associated chaperone complex serves as a sensor of physiological changes and mediates effects of such changes on heritable protein-based elements (prions). This provides a new mechanism for physiology and the environment to influence the hereditary constitution of the cell and organism. The project uses yeast as a model system and employs a combination of genetic, biochemical and proteomic techniques, including newly developed approaches for aggregate detection, potentially applicable beyond yeast.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: the long-term goal of this research is to investigate the cellular control and biological role of protein-based inheritance. Specifically, it is being studied how physiological changes regulate protein-based inheritance in yeast. Protein-based heritable elements are novel kind of genetic elements: they produce heritable changes in their host cells without any change in the DNA of their genes. This occurs by switching between protein isoforms, one of which (termed prion isoform and usually represented by fibrous protein aggregates, termed amyloids) is able to reproduce itself by inducing other molecules of the same protein to switch into the same isoform. This project was looking specifically at how these transitions are aided by another class of proteins, termed molecular chaperones, whose normal function is to promote correct protein folding and protect cells from environmental stresses.

The main objective of this project was to dissect the pathway connecting the protein synthesizing ribosomal machinery to the cellular apparatus of heritable protein aggregation. The unifying hypothesis was that the ribosome-associated chaperone complex serves as a sensor of physiological changes and mediates effects of such changes on heritable protein-based elements (prions). This provides a new mechanism for physiology and environment to influence the hereditary constitution of the cell and organism.

Obtained results show that the proteins of the ribosome-associated chaperone complex (Ssb-RAC), implicated in the folding of nascent polypeptide, modulate both de novo formation and propagation of various yeast prions. Release of the Hsp70-Ssb chaperone from the ribosome increases de novo prion formation but antagonizes prion propagation via interfering with the function of another chaperone, Hsp70-Ssa. Such a dual regulatory mechanism helps both to increase heritable variability at protein level and ameliorate its negative consequences. It is demonstrated that proteotoxic stress and chaperone sorting factors influence heritable protein aggregation via promoting relocalization of chaperones or cochaperones. A stress-induced metastable prion is discovered that may persist in a fraction of yeast cells after return to normal growth conditions, thus producing a cellular memory of stress and potentially generating a subpopulation of cells with an increased resistance to stress. Research on the project also helped to understand the role of translation termination factors in the ribosome quality control, and to decipher an impact of the yeast proteolytic machineries on heritable protein aggregation. 10 peer-reviewed papers, one non peer-reviewed paper and 2 juried conference abstracts were published, and 17 additional conference presentations were made on the basis of project-related materials. 

Broader impacts: understanding the physiological control of protein-based inheritance is important for the industrial use of yeast and other fungi. Research on the project was integrated with course development, teaching and mentoring, thus assuring educational benefits in the areas of genetics, biochemistry and bionanotechnology. 4 graduate and 9 undergraduate students (among them, two interns from other US institutions) participated in the project. Majority of students were females, and and the team included students from underrepresented minorities at both graduate and undergraduate levels, thus contributing to the diversity of the workforce training. Two Georgia Tech graduate students defended Ph.D. theses during their work on the project (with one of them continuing practical training on the project-related work as a postdoc), and three Georgia Tech undergraduate students graduated with B.Sc. degrees during the course of the project. A graduate student working on this project participated in the program providing a professional outreach to middle and high school teachers. The project also helped to strengthen research infrastructure by contributing to the development of interdisciplinary centers at Georgia Institute of Technology.
